question: Old fuck.
answer: Oh, my...

question: Out for a little stroll, Paulie?
answer: Let go...

question: What's with this poncho you got on, huh? This isn't yours.
answer: I got it off the wall there. There's a whole row of them.

question: But not for you, Paulie, that's the thing. Those are for the staff.
answer: I just borrowed it. Don't see what harm it does.

question: It's not about harm, it's about rules. You probably don't think an old fart like you has to mind rules anymore, but that's just not true.
answer: I'm sorry if I broke the rules.

question: You got no business up in those woods anyway, especially in the rain. What if you fall and bust a hip, huh? Who you think's gonna have to hoss your sorry old bacon back down here? Me, that's who.
answer: You're hurting me!

question: What do you do up there, anyway? You're too old to go jerk off, so what do you do?
answer: Nothing. I just walk, that's all, I like to walk!

question: We should report him.
answer: That might just provoke him all the more, make things worse for everybody.

question: It's not everybody he has it in for, Paul. It's you. What did you do to provoke him in the first place? Nothing. He's just an abusive bully, and should be made to stop.
answer: Ellie, please...

question: Paul? What is it? Paul...my God...
answer: It's okay...I'll be okay...

question: Mr. Edgecomb will be perfectly fine without your help, thank you.
answer: I guess sometimes the past just catches up with you, whether you want it to or not. It's silly.

question: Was it the film? It was, wasn't it?
answer: I haven't spoken of these things in a long time, Ellie. Over sixty years.

question: Paul. I'm your friend.
answer: Yes. Yes you are. I ever tell you I was a prison guard during the depression?

question: You've mentioned it.
answer: Did I mention I was in charge of death row? That I supervised all the executions? They usually call death row the Last Mile, but we called ours the Green Mile, because the floor was the color of faded limes. We had the electric chair then. Old Sparky, we called it. I've lived a lot of years, Ellie, but 1935 takes the prize. That was the year I had the worst urinary infection of my life. That was also the year of John Coffey, and the two dead girls...

question: Paul? Prisoner.
answer: Christ. Gimme a minute.

question: You all right in there?
answer: For a man pissing razor blades.

question: You should'a took the day off, gone to see the doctor.
answer: With a new arrival? You know better. Besides, it's not as bad as it was. I think it's clearing up.

question: Never you mind, Del, you just keep your nose quietly on your business.
answer: Damn, they're riding on the axle. What'd they do, bust the springs? Paul? You might wanna reconsider getting in the cell with this guy?

question: Why's that?
answer: He's enormous.

question: Can't be bigger than you.
answer: Dead man walking! Dead man walking here!

question: Jeezus, pleeze-us, what the hell's he yelling about?
answer: Dead man walking! Dead man walking! Dead man--

question: We'll get it looked at, Del, now keep yourself quiet like I said! If I let Harry take those chains off you, you gonna be nice? Your name is John Coffey.
answer: Yes, sir, boss, like the drink, only not spelt the same.

question: So you can spell, can you? My name is Paul Edgecomb. If I'm not here, you can ask for Mr. Terwilliger, Mr. Howell, or Mr. Stanton...those gentlemen there. This isn't like the rest of the prison. It's a quiet place, we like to keep it that way.
answer: It weren't me making all the noise, boss.

question: You having a joke on me, John Coffey?
answer: No, sir.

question: Your time here can be easy or hard, depends on you. If you behave, you get to walk in the exercise yard every day.
answer: Do you leave a light on after bedtime? Because I get a little scared in the dark sometimes. If it's a strange place.

question: It's pretty bright in here all night long. We keep half the lights burning in the corridor.
answer: Cor'der.

question: Right out there.
answer: Couldn't help it, boss. I tried to take it back, but it was too late.

question: How could I miss it, Harry? The whole prison heard.
answer: You'll probably have to answer for sending him off the Mile. He's gonna cause you trouble over this, you mark me.

question: I'll chew that food when I have to. Right now I wanna hear about the new inmate...aside from how big he is, okay?
answer: Monstrous big. Damn.

question: I interrupt?
answer: I'm just about done. How's that pretty gal of yours?

question: Melinda's not so well, Paul. Not so well at all. Got laid up with another headache yesterday. Worst one yet. She's also developed this weakness in her right hand.
answer: Doctor still think it's migraines?

question: I'll be taking her up to Indianola next day or so for some tests. Had X-rays and the like. She is scared to death. Truth to tell, so am I.
answer: If it's something they can see with an X-ray, maybe it's something they can fix.

question: Maybe. This just came in. D.O.E. on Bitterbuck.
answer: You didn't come all the way down here just to hand me a D.O.E.

question: No. I had an angry call from the state capital about twenty minutes ago. Is it true you ordered Percy Wetmore off the block.
answer: It is.

question: I'm sure you had reason, but like it or not, the wife of the governor of this state has only one nephew, and his name happens to be Percy Wetmore. I need to tell you how this lays out?
answer: Little Percy called his aunt and squealed like a schoolroom sissy. He also mention he assaulted a prisoner this morning out of sheer petulance? Broke three fingers on Eduard Delacroix's left hand.

question: I didn't hear that part. I'm sure she didn't either.
answer: The man is mean, careless, and stupid. Bad combination in a place like this. Sooner or later, he's gonna get somebody hurt. Or worse.

question: You and Brutus Howell will make sure that doesn't happen.
answer: Easy enough to say. We can't watch him every minute, Hal.

question: Stick with it. May not be much longer. I have it on good authority that Percy has an application in at Briar Ridge.
answer: The mental hospital?

question: Administration job. Better pay.
answer: Then why's he still here? He could get that application pushed through...hell, with his connections, he could have any state job he wants. Tell you what I think. I think he just wants to see one cook up close.

question: Well, he'll get his chance then, won't he? Maybe then he'll be satisfied and move on. In the meantime, you'll keep the peace.
answer: Of course.

question: Thank you, Paul.
answer: You give Melinda my love, okay? I bet that X-ray turns out to be nothing at all.

question: You give Melinda my love, okay? I bet that X-ray turns out to be nothing at all.
answer: Paul?

question: Hey, you. Music too loud?
answer: No. There's just this big empty spot in the bed where my husband usually sleeps.

question: He said to tell you he's having a little trouble with that tonight.
answer: Worried about Melinda and Hal? Is that what's got you up?

question: Yeah, that. Things.
answer: Things.

question: Got a new inmate today. Big, simple-minded fella.
answer: Do I want to hear what he did?

question: No. One sleepless member of this family's enough. The things that happen in this world. It's a wonder God allows it.
answer: Why don't you come to bed? I've got something to help you sleep, and you can have all you want.

question: Don't I wish. I've still got something wrong with my waterworks, I don't want to pass it on.
answer: You see Doc Sadler yet?

question: No, because he'll want me to take sulfa tablets and I'll spend the rest of the week puking in every corner of my office. It'll run its course all by itself, thank you very much for your concern.
answer: Poor old guy...

question: It ain't normal for a mouse to come up on people that way. Maybe it's rabid.
answer: Oh, my Christ. The big mouse expert. The Mouse Man. You see it foaming at the mouth, Mouse Man?

question: I don't see its mouth at all. Aw, Brutal, no! We'll be hip-deep in mice around here...
answer: I just wanna see what he'll do. In the interests of science, like.

question: All right. Let's get the damn mouse.
answer: Saw me a mouse go by.

question: It was a dream. Go back to sleep.
answer: Weren't no dream. It was a mouse all right.

question: Well, I'll be damned. There he is, big as Billy-be-frigged. I thought Brutal was pulling my leg.
answer: That's a goddamn mouse.

question: Yeah. Brute said he was in here last night begging for food, came right up to the desk.
answer: My ass. Give him some room, Percy, see what he does.

question: Brave little bastard, gotta give him that.
answer: Here, lemme try. Maybe he's full.

question: Men under strain can snap. Hurt themselves. Hurt others. That's why our job is talking, not yelling. You'll do better to think of this place like an intensive care ward in a hospital--
answer: I think of it as a bucket of piss to drown rats in. That's all. Anybody doesn't like it can kiss my ass. How's that sit? Try it. You'll be on the bread lines before the week is out.

question: We all know who your connections are, Percy... ...but you ever threaten a man on this block again, we're all gonna have a go. Job be damned.
answer: Big talk. You done?

question: What's up his ass?
answer: You, Percy. Always you.

question: You gotta hate the new boy? That the way it is around here?
answer: Why not just move on? Go to Briar Ridge. Yeah, I know about it. Sounds like a good job.

question: I might take it, too. Soon as you put me out front. You heard me. I want Brutal's spot for the next execution.
answer: What's with you? Seeing a man die isn't enough? You gotta be close enough to smell his nuts cook?

question: I wanna be out front, is all. Just one time. Then you'll be rid of me.
answer: If I say no?

question: Delacroix? That you? You are not gonna believe this.
answer: Look! I done tame me dat mouse!

question: We see that.
answer: Watch dis! Watch what he do! Ain't he sumpthin now? Ain't Mr. Jingles smart?

question: Mr. Jingles?
answer: Dat his name. He whisper it in my ear. Cap'n, can I have a box for my mouse so he can sleep in here wi' me?

question: I notice your English gets better when you want something.
answer: Wanna see what else he can do? Watch, watch, watch... We play fetch, Mr. Jingles? We play fetch? He fetch it ever' time. Smart as hell, ain't he? We do da trick again, watch, watch, watch...

question: That the one I chased?
answer: Yes, that's the one. Only Del says his name is Mr. Jingles.

question: Is that so?
answer: Del was just asking for a box. He thinks the mouse will sleep in it, I guess. That he might keep it for a pet. What do you think?

question: I think it'll shit up his nose some night and run away, but I guess that's Del's lookout. We oughtta find a cigar box. Get some cotton batting from he dispensary to line it with. That should do real nice.
answer: Man said get a cigar box. Hal? You wanted to see me?

question: Man said get a cigar box. Hal? You wanted to see me?
answer: Yeah. Paul. Close the door. Uh. So you know. You got a new prisoner coming in tomorrow. William Wharton. Young kid. Wild as hell, judging from this... ...been rambling all over the state last few years, causing all kinds of trouble. Finally hit big time. Killed three people in a holdup, including a pregnant woman. Got "Billy the Kid" tattooed on his left arm...bad news all around...

question: Hal?
answer: It's a tumor, Paul. A brain tumor. They got X-ray pictures of it. It's the size of a lemon, they said, and way down deep inside where they can't operate. They say she'll be dead by Christmas. I haven't told her. I can't think how. For the life of me, Paul, I can't think how to tell my wife she's going to die.

question: I'm going.
answer: What?

question: To the doctor. I'm going. Today. Just as soon as we get the new inmate squares away.
answer: That bad?

question: Yeeeeeeehaaaawwwwwwrooooo! WHOOOEE, BOYS! AIN'T THIS A PARTY, NOW? IS IT, OR WHAT?
answer: LET HIM GO!

question: G'WAN, SHOOT! SEE WHO YA HIT!
answer: HIT HIM, PERCY! GODDAMN IT, HIT HIM!

question: I've got the Mile till you all get back. Go on now.
answer: Boss? Needs ta see ya down here.

question: This is not a good time, John Coffey. Not a good time at all.
answer: But I needs ta see ya, boss. I needs ta talk t'ya. Closer.

question: I'm alone here right now, John. Figure this is close enough.
answer: Boss, please. I got to whisper in your ear.

question: You're imagining thing. Lie down, Del. Get you some rest.
answer: Hi, honey. How are you feeling?

question: Um...not too bad.
answer: What did the doctor say?

question: Oh, you know doctors. Gobble-de- gook mostly.
answer: Paul? What are you doing?

question: What's it feel like?
answer: I know what it feels like...it feels great...but...Paul... Those must've been some pills. Paul? Not that I'm complaining. But we haven't gone four times in one night since we were nineteen. You wanna tell me just what the hell's going on?

question: Well...thing is...I never actually got to the doctor yesterday... Brutal? Listen...I'm thinking of taking the morning off sick. You cover the fort for me? That's swell. Thanks. Yeah, I'm sure I'll feel better. Okay.
answer: You sure you ought to do this?

question: I'm not sure what I'm sure of. Yes, ma'am, a cold drink would be fine. Thank you. Mr. Hammersmith. Your office said I'd find you at home today. I hope I'm not troubling you.
answer: That depends, Mr.--?

question: Paul Edgecomb. I'm the E Block superintendant at Cold Mountain.
answer: The Green Mile. I've heard of it. Lost a few clients your way.

question: That's why I'm here. I'd like to ask you about one of them.
answer: Which client? Now you got my curiosity aroused.

question: John Coffey.
answer: Ah, Coffey. He causing you problems?

question: No, can't say he is. He doesn't like the dark. He cries on occasion. Other than that...
answer: Cries, does he? Well, he's got a lot to cry about, I'd say. You know what he did.

question: I read the court transcripts. Thank you, Missus.
answer: What exactly are you trying to find out? Satisfy my curiosity, I'll see if I can satisfy yours.

question: I've wondered if he ever did anything like that before.
answer: Why? Has he said anything?

question: No. But a man who does a thing like that has often developed a taste for it over time. Occurred to me it might be easy enough to follow his backtrail and find out. A man his size, and colored to boot, can't be that hard to trace.
answer: You'd think so, but you'd be wrong. Believe me, we tried. It's like he dropped out of the sky.

question: How do you explain that?
answer: We're in a Depression. A third of the country's out of work.

question: He's...strange, I admit. But there doesn't seem to be any real violence in him. I know violent men, Mr. Hammersmith. I deal with 'em day in and day out.
answer: You didn't come up here to ask me whether he might have killed before. You came up here to see if I think he did it at all. That's it, isn't it?

question: Do you?
answer: One seldom sees a less ambiguous case. He was found with the victims in his arms. Blurted out a confession right then and there.

question: Yet you defended him.
answer: Everyone is entitled to a defense. Y'all listen to your Momma, now! Tell you something. You listen close, too, because it might be something you need to know.

question: I'm listening.
answer: We had us a dog. No particular breed, but gentle. Ready to lick your hand or fetch a stick. Just a sweet mongrel, you know the kind. In many way, a good mongrel dog is like you negro. You get to know it, and often you get to love it. It is of no particular use, but you keep it around because you think it loves you. If you're lucky, Mr. Edgecomb, you never have to find out any different. My wife and I were not so lucky. Caleb. Come here for a second. Please, son. He has the one eye. I suppose he's lucky not to be blind. We get down on our knees and thank God for that much at least. Right Caleb? Okay, go on in now. That dog attacked my boy for no reason. Just got it into his mind one day. Same with John Coffey. He was sorry afterwards, of that I have no doubt...but those little girls stayed raped and murdered nonetheless. Maybe he's never done it before--my dog never bit before, but I didn't concern myself with that. I went out there with my rifle and grabbed his collar and blew his brains out.

question: I'm sorry for your trouble.
answer: I'm as enlightened as the next man, Mr. Edgecomb. I would not bring back slavery for all the tea in China. I believe we have to be humane and generous in our efforts to solve the race problem. But we have to remember that the negro will bite if he gets the chance, just like a mongrel dog will bite if it crosses its mind to do so. Is Coffey guilty? Yes, he is. Don't you doubt it, and don't you turn your back on him. You might get away with it once or even a hundred times...but in the end... You understand? I'm gonna have to tear that old doghouse down one of these days.

question: I'm smelling me some cornbread.
answer: It's from my missus. She wanted to thank you.

question: Thank me for what?
answer: You know. For helping me.

question: Helping you with what? Ohhh. Was your missus pleased?
answer: Several times.

question: Hey, d'jall like that? I'm currently cooking some turds t'go with it! Nice soft ones! I'll have 'em out t'yall tomorrow!
answer: We've been looking to clear that room out anyway.

question: Hey! Whassit now, movin' day? Y'all wanna come in and dust a little? Y'can shine my knob for me while yer at it! You can come in here on your legs, but you'll go out on your backs, Billy the Kid guarantee ya that. C'mon, fuckstick. No sneakin' up on me this time. We'll go man to man, see who's the better fel--
answer: C'mon, Wild Bill. Little walky walky.

question: What about Dean? He's got a little boy would love a pet mouse, I bet.
answer: How could a boy be trust wid Mr. Jingles? Maybe forget to feed him. And how he keep up wid his trainin', just a boy, n'est-ce pas?

question: All right, I'll take him.
answer: T'ank you kindly, merci beaucoup, but you live out in the woods, and Mr. Jingles, he be scared to live out dans la foret.

question: Hey! What dis Mouseville?
answer: Tourist attraction, I said. They got this big tent you go into--

question: Like a cirque? You have to pay?
answer: You shittin' me? Course you pay. Dime a piece, two cents for the kids. And inside the tent there's this mouse city made out of boxes and toilet paper rolls... ...plus they got the Mouseville All-Star Circus. There's mice that swing on trapeze, mice that roll barrels, mice that stack coins...

question: Dat's it! Dat's da place for Mr. Jingles! You gonna be a circus mouse after all! Gonna live in a mouse city down in Florida!
answer: Percy, no!

question: Brute, come along with me. You fellas go on back to you cribbage game.
answer: Don't start in on me. It was just a mouse. Never belonged here in the first place.

question: The mouse is fine. Just fine. You're no better at mouse-killing than anything else around here.
answer: You expect me to believe that? I heard the goddamn thing crunch.

question: Aren't you glad Mr. Jingles is okay? After all our talks about how we should keep the prisoners calm? Aren't you relieved?
answer: What kind of game is this?

question: No game. See for yourself.
answer: You switched them! You switched them somehow, you bastards!

question: You're playing with me, the both of you! Just who the hell do you think you are--
answer: We're the people you work with, Percy, but not for long. I want your word.

question: My word?
answer: I put you out front for Del, you put in your transfer to Briar Ridge the very next day.

question: What if I just call up certain people and tell them you're harassing me? Bullying me?
answer: Go ahead. I promise you'll leave your share of blood on the floor.

question: Over a mouse? You think anyone's gonna give two shits?
answer: No. But four men will swear you stood by while Wild Bill tried to strangle Dean to death. About that people will care, Percy. Even your uncle the governor will care.

question: I put you out front, you put in your transfer. That's the deal. You make a promise to a man, you shake his hand.
answer: Hey, boys. Say hi, Mr. Jingles.

question: Eduard Delacroix, will you step forward?
answer: Boss Edgecomb?

question: Yes, Del?
answer: Don' let nothin' happen to Mr. Jingles, okay? Here, take him.

question: Yeah, you take 'im, John. Take him til' dis foolishment done--bien! After, you take him down to Florida? To dat Mouseville?
answer: We'll do it together, most likely. Maybe take a little vacation time.

question: People pay a dime apiece to see him. Two cents for the kiddies. Ain't dat right, Boss Howell?
answer: That's right, Del.

question: How many years you spend pissing on the toilet seat before somebody told you to put it up?
answer: Percy fucked up, Hal. Pure and simple.

question: Is that your official position?
answer: Don't you think it should be? He'll be putting in a transfer request to Briar Ridge tomorrow. Moving on to bigger and better things. Isn't that right, Percy?

question: You're about ten seconds away from spending the rest of your life in the padded room.
answer: Poor Del. Poor old Del.

question: Yes. Poor old Del. John, are you okay?
answer: I could feel it from here.

question: What do you mean? You could hear it? Is that what you mean?
answer: He's out of it now, though. He's the lucky one. No matter how it happened, Del's the lucky one.

question: Where's Mr. Jingles?
answer: Ran down there. Don't think he'll be back. Awful tired now, boss. Dog tired.

question: She's having one of her good days. I thank God for that.
answer: What a bad day?

question: Sometimes she's...not herself anymore. She swears.
answer: Swears.

question: Hell, yes, I been behaved. C'mon, now, don't be stingy hogs.
answer: You gonna stay behaved?

question: C'mon, you clunk, gimme that.
answer: You promise me, or I'll drink it myself right here in front of you.

question: C'mon now, don't be that way. I be good.
answer: Cup.

question: We'll break out the fire hose and take it anyway. And you will have drunk your last R.C. cola. Unless they serve 'em down in hell.
answer: Anybody wants to back out, now's the time. After this, there's no turning back. So? We gonna do this?

question: He's a bad man. They're still in there. Pieces of them, still in there. I hear them screaming.
answer: John, come along! Right now, y'hear? C'mon! Toward that door! Lie down on this. It'll be easier for you and no harder for us.

question: Say. This is fun. Look, boss! It's Cassie, the lady in the rocking chair!
answer: Shhh. John, you have to be quiet now.

question: Hey there, little firefly. Where's Mrs. Firefly this evening? Oh, there you is. You come out to play too?
answer: They seem...drawn to you.

question: I love 'em, is why. They don't think no hurtful thoughts. They's just happy to be. Happy little lightning bugs...
answer: C'mon, big boy. Upsy-daisy. John? Do you know where we're taking you?

question: Help a lady?
answer: That's right. Help a lady. But how did you know?

question: Too late now. Harry, keep John here until we call you.
answer: Who the hell goes there at two- thirty in the goddamn morning?

question: Hal, it's us! It's Paul and Brutal--it's us!
answer: Paul, what are you doing here at this hour? Jesus, it's not a lockdown, is it? Or a riot?

question: Hal, God's sakes, take your finger off the trigger...
answer: Are you hostages? Who's out there? Who's by that truck? John Coffey! Halt! Halt right there or I shoot!

question: Boss, you just be quiet now and let me be.
answer: Stay out of here! Whoever you are, just stay out! I'm not dressed for visitors, you rat's asshole! Oh, so big! Pull down your pants! Let's have a look! Don't come near me, pigfucker. Why do you have so many scars? Who hurt you so badly?

question: Don't hardly remember, ma'am.
answer: What's your name?

question: John Coffey, ma'am. Like the drink, only not spelt the same. Ma'am?
answer: Yes, John Coffey?

question: Did I have the X-ray? Did I
answer: Yes. It was clear. There was no tumor.

question: Who is that man?
answer: John? Can you turn around? Can you turn around and see this lady?

question: Get me out of this nut-coat.
answer: In a minute.

question: Now! Now! Right n--
answer: You shut up and listen. You deserved to be punished for what you did to Del. You'll accept it like a man, or we'll make you sorry you were ever born. We'll tell people how you sabotaged Del's execution--

question: Sabotaged!
answer: --and how you pissed yourself like a frightened little girl. Yes, we'll talk, that's a given--but, Percy, mind me now...we'll also see you beaten within an inch of your life. We know people, too, are you so foolish you don't realize that? People with friends and loved ones doing time in this prison. People who'd be happy to amputate you nose or your penis just so someone they care about could get an extra three hours in the exercise yard every week. Let bygones be bygones. Nothing's hurt so far but your pride...and nobody need ever know about that except the people in this room.

question: Punished them bad men.
answer: Why Wild Bill? Why?

question: I saw in his heart. When he grab my arm, I saw what Wild Billy done. Saw plain as day. Can't hide what's in your heart.
answer: What? Saw what?

question: Why not? Just why the hell not?
answer: Because he's a six-foot-eight-inch baldheaded black man with barely enough brains to feed himself. How long you think it'd be before he was recaptured? Two hours? Six?

question: Do you mean to kill him, you cowards? Do you? Don't touch me! Next week this time you'll be a murderer, no better than that man Wharton, so don't touch me! I'm so sorry I called you a coward. I feel worse about that than anything I've ever said to you in our whole marriage.
answer: Even that time we went camping and you called me Old Stinky Sam?

question: Does Hal know? That Coffey's innocent, I mean? Can he help? Does he have the influence to do something about this?
answer: No.

question: Then don't tell him. If he can't help, don't tell him. Ever.
answer: I won't.

question: There's no way out of this for you, is there?
answer: No. I've been thinking about it, too, believe me. Tell you the truth, honey. I've done some things in my life I'm not proud of, but this is the first time I've ever felt in real danger of hell.

question: Hello, boss.
answer: Hello, John. I guess you know we're coming down to it now. Another couple of days. Is there anything special you'd like for dinner that night? We can rustle you up most anything.

question: Meatloaf be nice. Mashed taters with gravy. Okra, maybe. I's not picky.
answer: What about a preacher? Someone you could say a little prayer with?

question: Don't want no preacher. You can say a prayer, if you want. I could get kneebound with you, I guess.
answer: Me? S'pose I could, if it came to that. John, I have to ask you something very important right now.

question: I know what you gonna say. You don' have to say it.
answer: I do. I do have to. John, tell me what you want me to do. You want me to take you out of here? Just let you run away? See how far you can get?

question: Why would you do such a foolish thing?
answer: On the day of my judgement, when I stand before God, and He asks me why did I kill one of his true miracles, what am I gonna say? That is was my job? My job?

question: You tell God the Father it was a kindness you done. I know you hurtin' and worryin', I can feel it on you, but you oughtta quit on it now. Because I want it over and done. I do. I'm tired, boss. Tired of bein' on the road, lonely as a sparrow in the rain. Tired of not ever having me a buddy to be with, or tell me where we's coming from or going to, or why. Mostly I'm tired of people being ugly to each other.
answer: Yes, John. I think I can.

question: I be all right, fellas. This here's the hard part. I be all right in a little while.
answer: John, I should have that just for now. I'll give it back after.

question: You know, I fell asleep this afternoon and had me a dream. I dreamed about Del's mouse.
answer: Did you, John?

question: I dreamed he got down to that place Boss Howell talked about, that Mouseville place. I dreamed there was kids, and how they laughed at his tricks! My! I dreamed those two little blonde- headed girls were there. They 'us laughing, too. I put my arms around 'em and sat 'em on my knees, and there 'us no blood comin' outta their hair and they 'us fine. We all watch Mr. Jingles roll that spool, and how we did laugh. Fit to bus', we was.
answer: What should we pray for, John?

question: Strength?
answer: God, please help us finish what we've started, and please welcome this man, John Coffey--like the drink, but not spelled the same-- into heaven and give him peace. Please help us to see him off the best we can and let nothing go wrong. Amen.

question: I know a prayer I once heard. Can I say it?
answer: You go right ahead, John. Take all the time you need.

question: Roll on two. That was the last execution I ever took part in. Just couldn't do it anymore after that. Brutal either. We both transferred out, took jobs with Boys' Correctional. That was all right. Catch 'em young, that became my motto. Might even have done some good. You don't believe me.
answer: I don't imagine you would lie to me, Paul. It's just that...

question: ...It's quite a story.
answer: Yes. Quite a story. One thing I don't understand. You said you and Jan had a grownup son in 1935. Is that right? But if that's true...

question: The math doesn't work, does it? You feel up to a walk? There. It's in there.
answer: Paul? This thing you want to show me. Is it scary?

question: Scary? No. Not really. There. Hey. Wake up, old boy. Wake up.
answer: Paul? It isn't...it can't be...

question: Come over here, boy. Come on over her and see this lady.
answer: That can't be Mr. Jingles.

question: Messieurs et mesdames. Beinvenue au cirque du mousie.
answer: Oh, Paul. Don't make him do it again. I can't bear to watch.

question: But he loves it so much. This isn't exactly the Mouseville we had in mind...but we make do, don't we, old fella?
answer: As I live and breathe! Fooled you, didn't I Got yourself a little love nest here, I see... ...what the fuck? Is that a mouse?

question: Don't hurt him, okay? Okay?
answer: It's a goddamn mouse, y'old fool, they carry all kind'a disease... ...now step aside.

question: You leave him alone, Percy! You leave him alone, or by God I'll--
answer: Who you calling Percy? Name's Brad, you senile fucker. And I'm gonna nail that mouse, you can take that to the everfucking bank.

question: Who you calling Percy? Name's Brad, you senile fucker. And I'm gonna nail that mouse, you can take that to the everfucking bank.
answer: How dare you? Get out!

question: Piss off, you wrinkeldy old bitch. Me and Paulie are talking.
answer: His name is Mr. Edgecomb. If you ever call him Paulie again, your days of employment at Georgia Pines will end.

question: Who the hell you think you are?
answer: I am the grandmother of the man who is currently Speaker of the Georgia House of Representatives. A man who loves his relatives, Mr. Dolan. All it would take is a phone call. At first I thought I'd let you be. I'm old, and that seemed easiest. But when my friends are threatened and abused, I do not let it be. Now get out, or you won't work another day here. Not another hour. I swear it.

question: Don't know what you're getting so het up about. Just a damn mouse.
answer: Get out, you ignorant man. What little mind you have is ugly and misdirected.

question: Don't bother coming back here tomorrow...Mr. Edgecomb Gonna be a new lock on this door. This is off-limits to residents, no matter what Mrs. My Shit Don't Stink has to say about it.
answer: Little trick I learned from Percy Wetmore.
